More details about these sickness benefits and what you need to show can be found in Chapter 11.
section_text:
In order to establish eligibility for sickness benefits the claimant must demonstrate that he or she is incapable of work by reason of a prescribed illness or injury, and would otherwise be available for work.
Exception: Claimants in receipt of EI parental benefits who wish to convert their parental benefits to sickness benefits, and who provide proof of incapacity, are exempt from proving they are otherwise available for work.
The claimant may be required to provide a medical certificate completed by his or her physician or appropriate medical authority, as proof of the inability to work.
The claimant is required to provide a medical certificate as proof of the inability to work completed by his or her physician or appropriate medical authority.
The Commission has medical advisers available to act as resource persons for those complex or ambiguous questions that require a medical opinion or recommendation.
The Commission also has full authority to require the claimant to undergo an independent medical examination if it considers it appropriate to do so in order to prove incapacity. Failure to comply may be a ground for denying benefits.
Referral by the agent to a medical adviser, of referral of the claimant to an independent medical examination occurs only when it is considered necessary so as to counterbalance certain information on file, to answer questions on the state of the claimant's health, or to clarify cases of incapability that are complex, ambiguous or contradictory.
Because sickness benefits are limited to persons who would be entitled to regular benefits were it not for their illness or injury; the claimant must also prove that he or she would have been otherwise available for work (other than while receiving parental benefits). Availability will be determined in the same way as if the person was capable of work, i.e. reason for separation, personal situation, intentions, requirements and restrictions in relation to the labour market   .
Sickness benefits and what constitutes proof in these situations are discussed in Chapter 11   .

simplified_text: In order to receive maternity benefits, the person applying needs to give a statement about their pregnancy and the expected or actual date they will give birth.
section_text: In the case of a claim for maternity benefits the onus is on the claimant to provide a statement advising of her pregnancy and her expected or actual date of confinement.

simplified_text: To get parental benefits, parents just need to provide a statement with the baby's birth date. If it's for adoption benefits, they need to give a statement saying they want to adopt, along with the adoption agency's information.
section_text: For parental  benefits, a declaration by the claimant advising the infant's date of birth or  for the purposes of adoption, their intent to adopt as well as the placement  date and the name and address of the adoption authority is accepted as proof   .

simplified_text: To get compassionate care benefits, you need to provide medical evidence to the Commission stating that your family member is very sick with a serious condition that could lead to death within 26 weeks. They also need to require care or support from one or more family members.
section_text:
In order to receive compassionate care benefits, medical proof must be  furnished to the Commission indicating that the gravely ill family member has:

a serious medical condition  with a significant risk of death within 26 weeks, and
requires the care or  support of one or more family members.

simplified_text: FCB benefits are available for individuals who are very sick and need their family members to take care of them. A medical doctor or nurse practitioner must provide a signed document confirming the patient's critical condition and the need for family care. This document should also specify how long the patient will require this care.
section_text:
FCB benefits require medical proof signed by a medical doctor or nurse practitioner which states that:

the patient is critically ill and requires the care or support of one or more of their family members; and
sets out the period during which the patient requires that care  or support.

simplified_text:
In June 2013, a law called the Employment Insurance Legislation was created to help parents of seriously ill children. As of December 3, 2017, improvements were made to these benefits and they are now called family caregiver benefits for children. These benefits allow a parent to get paid time off work to take care of a child who is very sick or injured. The parent doesn't need to look for another job while getting these benefits.

A person can get up to 35 weeks of family caregiver benefits for kids in a year, whether all the weeks go to one person or are shared among family members. There's a limit of 35 weeks per claim. 

On December 3, 2017, the law also started family caregiver benefits for adults. These benefits allow someone to get paid time off work to take care of an adult who is seriously ill or injured.

For adults, a person can get up to 15 weeks of family caregiver benefits in a year, which can be given to one person or divided among family members. There's a limit of 15 weeks per claim. 

The law can make more rules about what counts as taking care of someone, who can give a medical note, when the time limit can be longer than a year, when the wait time before benefits start can be postponed, and what happens if family members can't agree on how to share the weeks of benefits.

In this law, the term "family member" refers to someone approved as family under the Employment Insurance Regulations.
section_text:
In June 2013, the Employment Insurance (EI) Legislation introduced parents of critically ill children benefits   . Effective December 3, 2017, enhancements were done to these benefits and they have been renamed family caregiver benefits for children. These benefits allow an eligible claimant to receive income support while absent from work to provide care or support for a critically ill or injured child. Individuals are not required to be available for work to receive this type of benefit   .
The legislation provides for the payment of a maximum of 35 weeks of family caregiver benefits for children within a 52 week window   , whether they are paid to one family member, or shared between two or more family members . A claimant can only receive a maximum of 35 weeks of family caregiver benefits for children per benefit period   .
On December 3, 2017, the EI Legislation introduced family caregiver benefits for adults.  These benefits allow an eligible claimant to receive income support while absent from work to provide care or support for a critically ill or injured adult.
The legislation provides for the payment of a maximum of 15 weeks of family caregiver benefits for adults within a 52 week window, whether they are paid to one family member, or shared between two or more of the critically ill adult's eligible family members. A claimant can only receive a maximum of 15 weeks of family caregiver benefits for adults per benefit period. 

The Act provides for the making of regulations to further define and determine what is care or support   ; who can issue a medical certificate   ; in which situations a longer period than 52 weeks applies   ; when a waiting period can be deferred   ; and prescribing rules when claimants do not agree on the division of weeks of benefits   .

Throughout this chapter, for ease of reference, the expression family member is used to describe an approved family member as defined in the Employment Insurance Regulations.

simplified_text: The law allows family members to get paid benefits while taking care of a critically ill child or adult. To qualify, a medical doctor or nurse practitioner must issue a certificate stating that the child or adult is critically ill and needs care from their family members. This certificate must also mention the period for which the care is needed.
section_text:
The legislative authority to pay family caregiver benefits for children reads as follows   :
Despite section 18, but subject to this section, benefits are payable to a major attachment claimant, who is a family member of a critically ill child, in order to care for or support that child if a  medical doctor or nurse practitioner has issued a certificate that;

States that the child is a critically ill child and requires the care or support of one or more of their family members; and
Sets out the period during which the child requires that care or support.

The legislative authority to pay family caregiver benefits for adults reads as follows:
Despite section 18, but subject to this section, benefits are payable to a major attachment claimant who is a family member of a critically ill adult, in order to care for or support that adult, if a medical doctor or nurse practitioner has issued a certificate that


  states that the adult is a critically ill adult and requires the care or support of one or more of their familymembers; and
sets out the period during which the adult requires that care or support.

simplified_text: Family caregiver benefits are payments that are given to family members who are eligible to take care of a child or an adult who is very sick or needs assistance.
section_text: Family caregiver benefits are available to an eligible family member(s) for the purpose of providing care or support to a critically ill child   , or adult, also referred to in this chapter as care recipient.

simplified_text: For family caregiver benefits, a family member can be: spouse, child, parent, sibling, grandparent, grandchild, uncle, aunt, nephew, niece, foster parent, foster child, ward, guardian, or someone who is like a close relative. This includes the spouse or partner of these family members.
section_title: Claimants who can receive family caregiver benefits
section_text:
For the purposes of entitlement to family caregiver benefits, the term family member in relation to the care recipient, means any one of the following   :

 Spouse or common-law partner 
Child, their spouse or common-law partner
Child of spouse or common-law partner, their spouse or common-law partner
Parent, their spouse or common-law partner
Parent of spouse or common-law partner, their spouse or common-law partner
Sibling, step-sibling, their spouse or common-law partner
Sibling, step-sibling of spouse or common-law partner
Grandparent, their spouse or common-law partner
Grandparent of spouse or common-law partner
Grandchild, their spouse or common-law partner
Grandchild of spouse or common-law partner
Uncle, aunt, their spouse or common-law partner
Uncle, aunt of spouse or common-law partner
Nephew, niece, their spouse or common-law partner
Nephew, niece of spouse or common-law partner
Current or former foster parent
Current or former foster parent of spouse or common-law partner
Current or former foster child, their spouse or common-law partner
Current or former ward
Current or former ward of spouse or common-law partner
Current or former guardian, their spouse or common-law partner or
A person who is considered to be like a close relative, whether or not related by blood, adoption, marriage or common-law partnership

simplified_text: The person applying for family caregiver benefits should have stopped working and have worked at least 600 hours in their qualifying period. If someone has taken time off work, they will need more than 600 hours of work to be eligible for these benefits. Even if someone is currently receiving EI benefits, they can still apply for family caregiver benefits. To qualify, the person applying needs to provide a medical certificate for the seriously ill child or adult they are caring for. The child must be under 18, while the adult must be 18 or older. Self-employed individuals who have opted into the EI program can also access family caregiver benefits.
section_text:
The individual claiming family caregiver benefits must have experienced an interruption of earnings    from employment, and be major attached   , that is, have 600 hours of insurable employment in their qualifying period   .
In situations where a claimant has accumulated a violation, the claimant will require more than 600 hours of insurable employment during the qualifying period   , to be eligible for family caregiver benefits    .
Individuals who are unemployed and already receiving EI benefits can also apply and may be entitled to family caregiver benefits.
The individual claiming family caregiver benefits must submit a medical certificate with regard to the critically ill child or adult   . The critically ill child must be under the age of 18 years. The critically ill adult must be 18 years old or older. 
Family caregiver benefits are accessible to self-employed persons    who have voluntarily registered into the EI program   .

simplified_text:
To qualify for assistance, a person needs to provide a medical certificate signed by a medical doctor or nurse practitioner. A nurse practitioner is a registered nurse who, in a province, can work as a nurse practitioner independently â€“ this means they can make diagnoses, order tests, prescribe medicines, and treat patients. The medical certificate must state that the patient's life is in danger due to an illness or injury, there has been a significant change in the patient's health, and the patient needs care from family members.

If the critically ill person is outside Canada, the claimant must provide a medical certificate from a doctor or nurse practitioner who has similar qualifications to a medical doctor, as recognized by the appropriate government authority.

The certificate should include the name, address, and birthdate of the critically ill person. Only one certificate is needed if multiple people will share the benefits.

Medical professionals cannot share a patient's medical information without the patient's consent or unless it's required by law. The patient needs to sign a form allowing their doctor to share their medical details with the authorities. If the patient can't consent, their authorized representative must sign the form. If the medical certificate doesn't come with this consent form, the claimant won't receive benefits.
section_title: Proof of critically ill or injured child or adult
section_text:
An eligible claimant must submit a medical certificate, which must be completed and signed by a medical doctor or nurse practitioner  .
 Nurse Practitioner is defined as a registered nurse who, under the laws of a province, is entitled to practice as a nurse practitioner — or under an equivalent designation — and to autonomously make diagnoses, order and interpret diagnostic tests, prescribe substances and treat patients.
The medical doctor or nurse practitioner must issue a medical certificate that indicates:

 The patient's life is at risk as a result of an illness or injury
There has been a significant change in the patient's baseline state of health; and
The patient requires the care or support of one or more family members

For cases in which the critically ill child or adult resides outside Canada, it will be necessary for the claimant to submit a medical certificate completed by a medical doctor or nurse practitioner  who is recognized by the appropriate government authority with similar qualifications to a medical doctor    .
The certificate will identify the critically ill child or adult - the medical doctor's or nurse practitioner's patient - by providing the complete name, address and date of birth of the patient. When more than one claimant will share the benefits, only one certificate is required.
Medical professionals are not authorized to release medical information without the patient's consent, or unless required by law. A separate form must be signed by the patient, to authorize the  medical doctor or nurse practitioner to release medical information on the patient, to the Commission. If the patient is incapable of consenting to the release of medical information for reasons of his/her age or a physical or mental condition, the authorization form must be completed by the patient's legally authorized or appointed representative. If a medical certificate is not accompanied by the authorization to release medical information for the patient, the claimant will be disentitled from benefits.

simplified_text: Care is all the help someone needs because of their health, aside from what a doctor provides. Support is all the emotional help someone needs because of their health. This help can include spending time each day with someone who is seriously ill in their home, hospice, or medical facility. If someone is taking care of a seriously ill person and needs a short break, they can still get benefits. Each case will be looked at individually to decide if the benefits should continue. If it's clear that someone is not giving care or support as defined, they won't get benefits anymore. This is important to keep in mind when applying for these benefits.
section_title: Care or support of critically ill or injured child or adult
section_text:
Care    is defined as: all care that is required because of a care recipient's state of health, other than the care provided by a health care professional.
Support    is defined as: all psychological or emotional support that is required because of a care recipient's state of health.
The definition of care or support may also include situations where the claimant simply spends time each day with the critically ill care recipient in the home, a hospice or a medical facility. 
It is recognized that an individual claiming this type of  benefits may require a short break from providing care or support for the  critically ill care recipient. Therefore benefits would not be automatically denied when  the claimant does not actually provide care for only a few days. The  determination of whether a claimant continues to prove entitled to benefits will  be considered based on the merits of each individual case.
In any situation, if it becomes apparent that the claimant  is not providing care or support, based on the definitions above, the claimant  will be disentitled from benefits.

simplified_text: This rule sets a limit on how long family caregivers can receive benefits for taking care of a child. The most that can be paid out is 35 weeks in a row. This limit still applies whether one person claims all the benefits or if different family members share them.
section_text:
The legislation provides two caps to the maximum number of weeks payable for family caregiver benefits for children.

A maximum of 35 weeks of family caregiver benefits for children is payable within a benefit period    
A maximum of 35 weeks of family caregiver benefits for children payable within the 52 week family caregiver window, in relation to a critically ill child    

These limitations apply whether the benefits are claimed by one individual or shared with the child's other family members.

simplified_text: The new law has set a limit on the number of weeks that family members can receive caregiver benefits. A person can receive up to 15 weeks of caregiver benefits during a benefit period and also within a 52-week window for family caregiving. These restrictions apply whether one person claims all the benefits or if they are shared among family members.
section_text:
The new legislation provides two caps to the maximum number of weeks payable for family caregiver benefits for adults. 

A maximum of 15 weeks of family caregiver benefits for adults is payable within a benefit period
A maximum of 15 weeks of family caregiver benefits for adults is payable within the 52 week family caregiver window  . 

These limitations apply whether these benefits are claimed by one individual or shared with other family members.

simplified_text: Family caregiver benefits are available for up to 52 weeks to people who qualify. They can get these benefits to take care of a family member who is very sick. The specific number of weeks for benefits depends on if the sick person is a child or an adult. To start receiving these benefits, a medical certificate needs to be provided, and a family member of the sick person needs to request the benefits for the first time.
section_text: Family caregiver benefits are available within a 52 week window, to eligible claimants to provide care or support to a critically ill care recipient. This 52 week window during which the 35 weeks of family caregiver benefits for children or 15 weeks for family caregiver benefits for adults may be paid is determined by both the issuance of a medical certificate and a first request for these benefits by a family member of the critically ill care recipient.

simplified_text:
In the EI Act, it explains that family caregiver benefits can be paid to someone who is looking after a critically ill family member. The benefits start either from the day the first medical certificate is issued or if the claim was made before the certificate, from the day the doctor says the family member is critically ill.

The first valid medical certificate sets off a 52-week period for the benefits. If a later certificate shows an earlier illness date, it won't change the benefit window if all payments have been made, or if the window has already started and moving it earlier affects payments to someone already getting benefits.

This rule makes sure that new information won't affect benefits already given to another caregiver. Sometimes, new medical certificates might come with changes, which could lead to a review of the benefits.
section_title: Start of the family caregiver window
section_text:
Subsection 23.2 (3) and Subsection 23.3(3) of the EI Act, states that family caregiver benefits can be paid in the period that begins in the week in which either of the following falls:

the day of issuance of the first valid medical certificate that is submitted to the Commission, or
in the case of a claim that is made before the day on which the medical certificate is issued, the day from which the medical doctor or nurse practitioner certifies that the care recipient is critically ill

The first medical certificate submitted that meets the requirements of the legislation, will determine the start of the 52 week window. A subsequent medical certificate that indicates an earlier date on which the critically ill care recipient became ill will not be accepted to change the start of the window when: 

all benefits in relation to that claim have already been paid at the time the certificate is filed with the Commission, or
the start of the 52 week window has already been determined regarding the critically ill care recipient, and the certificate would have the effect of moving the beginning of that period to an earlier date

This provision will ensure that a subsequent certificate submitted will not impact any family caregiver benefits already paid to another eligible claimant, for the same critically ill care recipient.
There may be rare cases where a medical certificate is received with an amendment to the information provided on a previous medical certificate. As in any other situation where amended information is received, the claim may be reconsidered, keeping in mind the provisions of the family caregiver benefits  legislation.

simplified_text: When you need to apply for family caregiver benefits, and you have a medical certificate already, the 52-week period begins either on the date the doctor confirms a family member is critically ill and needs care from you, or on the date the doctor states these conditions existed before. If you're asking for benefits for weeks before you got the medical certificate, the date can go back to when the patient was examined before, even if it was before the certificate was signed. The starting date for the 52-week period should be chosen to cover the weeks you need support for.
section_title: Medical certificate issued before family caregiver benefits claimed
section_text:
Where the medical certificate is issued before the family caregiver benefits claim is made, the 52 week window starts with either:

the date of examination of the critically ill family member where the doctor or nurse practitioner certifies that the two conditions exist: the patient has a serious medical condition where life is at risk and the patient requires the care of support of one or more family members, or
the date which the medical doctor or nurse practitioner attests that the two conditions applied at an earlier period of time

Where benefits are requested for weeks prior to  the week of signature of the medical certificate, information that the  conditions for family caregiver benefits applied to an earlier date may be  present. This can be the date of the last medical examination or an earlier  date on which the conditions applied, as indicated in the medical, rather than  the date of signature. The date which will be used to start the 52 week window  should be the one which will accommodate the weeks the claimant is requesting.

simplified_text:
After you claim family caregiver benefits, a 52-week period begins for eligibility. This countdown starts either from the day a medical doctor or nurse practitioner signs the medical certificate, or from the day the critically ill family member is examined by the doctor or nurse practitioner. The examination must confirm two things: that the family member is critically ill with a life-threatening condition and requires care from one or more family members. If the doctor or nurse practitioner confirms that these conditions existed earlier, then the 52-week period would begin from that earlier date. 

If you need benefits for weeks before the medical certificate is signed, the information confirming the family caregiver benefit conditions existed earlier can be used. This could include the date of the last medical examination or an earlier date when the conditions were present, as stated in the medical records. The starting date for the 52-week period should be chosen to cover all the weeks you are requesting benefits for.
section_title: Medical certificate issued after family caregiver benefits are claimed
section_text:
Where the medical certificate is issued after family caregiver benefits are claimed, the 52 week window starts with either:

the date the certificate is signed by the medical doctor or nurse practitioner, or
the date of examination of the critically ill family member where the doctor or nurse practitioner certifies that the two conditions exist: the patient has a serious medical condition where life is at risk and the patient requires the care or support of one or more family members, or
the date which the medical doctor or nurse practitioner attests that the two conditions applied at an earlier period of time

Where benefits are requested for weeks prior to the week of signature of the medical certificate, information that the conditions for family caregiver benefits applied to an earlier date may be present. This can be the date of the last medical examination or an earlier date on which the conditions applied, as indicated in the medical, rather than the date of signature. The date which will be used to start the 52 week window should be the one which will accommodate the weeks the claimant is requesting.

simplified_text:
The family caregiver window lasts for 52 weeks. Within this time frame, a person can get either 35 weeks of benefits for taking care of children or 15 weeks for taking care of adults. These weeks of benefits don't have to be used all at once and can be spaced out as needed, as long as the person can provide medical proof that the person they're caring for is critically ill. 

After certain events happen like reaching the maximum number of weeks allowed or the care recipient no longer needing care, the benefits will stop. If the critically ill person dies before the 52 weeks are up, benefits will end that week, but the caregiver might still need time off for the funeral. If the person recovers or the illness improves, benefits will end when the care isn't needed anymore. 

If the same illness returns or if there's a new medical certificate, a new 52-week period can start. However, the total weeks of benefits can't go over 35 for children or 15 for adults in one period. If there are weeks left unused from the first 52-week period, they can be used in the new period. Benefits can also be shared with other family members if they are eligible.

The law says that if a family member is really sick, one person or more can share up to 35 weeks of benefits to take care of a sick child, or up to 15 weeks to take care of a sick adult. Everyone who can get these benefits must agree on how to share the weeks. These benefits can be received by more than one person at the same time, as long as they have medical proof. 

If more than one person wants to share these benefits but can't agree on how to split the weeks, the extra weeks will be divided equally if they can be, or the extra week goes to the person who asked for the benefits first. If there are fewer weeks left than people who want the benefits, they'll be given out in the order people applied for them.
section_text:
The legislation provides that the 35 weeks of family caregiver benefits for children and 15 weeks of family caregiver benefits for adults in relation to a critically ill care recipient can be shared by one or more eligible claimants, and that the weeks are to be divided as agreed to by those claimants    . The weeks of benefits can be claimed anywhere within the 52 week family caregiver window, subject to medical proof, and can be received concurrently by eligible claimants.
When these benefits are shared, it must be determined whether the other family member is claiming or has claimed family caregiver benefits to care for the same critically ill care recipient, and the number of weeks being claimed by the other family member.
When eligible claimants cannot come to an agreement, the remaining weeks will be divided based on the prescribed rules    in the following manner: 

When the number of weeks left to be paid can be divided equally between the eligible claimants, each claimant will be paid an equal number of weeks.
When the number of weeks left to be paid cannot be divided equally (odd number of weeks remaining) between the eligible claimants, the remaining weeks will be divided equally to the extent possible, and the extra week will be assigned to the eligible claimant who made their claim for family caregiver benefits first.
When the number of weeks left to be paid is less than the number of eligible claimants, the weeks will be distributed in the order in which the eligible claimants made their claim for family caregiver benefits

simplified_text: If more than one family member is seriously ill because of the same event or different events, they can each have up to 35 weeks of benefits per child or 15 weeks per adult. This rule applies for each family member and each sick person in a 52-week period. This means that different family members caring for different sick people can all receive benefits, but they can't get benefits for taking care of more than one sick person at the same time.
section_title: More than one critically ill care recipient
section_text: If more than one care recipient is critically ill as a result of the same event or unrelated events, a separate 52 week window may be established for each of the care recipients. However, the maximum number of weeks of family caregiver benefits payable is 35 per child, or 15 per adult, during the related 52 week window, as well as during a benefit period   .\r\n      This means that two family members could each establish a benefit period, one in respect of one care recipient, and the other in respect of the other  care recipient, and be payable the maximum weeks each. Neither family member can collect benefits in relation to both care recipients simultaneously.

simplified_text: Once someone is approved as a family caregiver for a critically ill person, other family members cannot receive compassionate care benefits for that same person until either the caregiver benefits have all been used up or until a year has passed. After the caregiver benefits are used up, compassionate care benefits can be paid out as long as all the requirements for the compassionate care benefits are still met.
section_text: Once a family caregiver window has been established, compassionate care benefits are not payable in respect of the critically ill care recipient. This means that no other family member can access compassionate care benefits in relation to the critically ill care recipient, until all related family caregiver benefits are exhausted, or until the 52 week period has expired    .\nCompassionate care benefits may be paid for the care recipient, after family caregiver benefits have exhausted, provided all other qualifying and entitlement conditions for compassionate care benefits are met.

simplified_text:
When someone asks to change the start date of their family caregiver benefits, the usual rules will be followed. However, there are specific rules to follow when making this request: if a certain amount of caregiver benefits have already been paid, or if the maximum period of benefits has already been set by another person, then the start date cannot be changed. This rule is in place to make sure that changing the start date for one person does not take away benefits that someone else has already received.

In some cases, people might not apply for caregiver benefits right away because they are busy taking care of a sick family member. In these situations, a more understanding approach will be used, similar to what is done for other special benefits, while still considering the specific rules mentioned above.
section_text:
Standard adjudication principles will apply when a claimant requests an antedate of a claim for family caregiver benefits. However, the legislation provides that, when an antedate is requested for family caregiver benefits, the benefit period cannot be antedated if, at the time the claim is made:

 35 weeks of family caregiver benefits for children have been paid; or,
15 weeks of family caregiver benefits for adults have been paid; or,
the 52-week family caregiver window has already been established by another claimant, and establishing the claim on the earlier date would move the start date of the window to an earlier date

This provision ensures that a request to antedate a claim for family caregiver benefits by one claimant will not affect the previous entitlement of the other claimant    .
Taking into account the nature of family caregiver benefits, there may be occasions where individuals delay in making a claim for benefits. When a claimant is prevented from making a claim by reason of providing care or support to a critically ill care recipient, a lenient approach will be applied, in the same manner as for other special benefits, keeping in mind the specific provisions mentioned above

simplified_text:
When a family member applies for caregiver benefits, they usually have to wait a week before they start getting the benefits. If multiple family members are sharing the benefits for taking care of one person, only one person needs to wait that one week period for each year. This means the first person who applies for the benefits needs to wait, but the others sharing the benefits can start without waiting, as long as someone already served that wait period for that year.
If two family members apply for caregiver benefits at the same time for the same person, they need to decide who will wait for that one week period before getting the benefits.
The first person who applies usually has to wait that one week in order for others to not have to wait. 
If the wait period was waived for the first person who applied but another family member applies for the same benefits in the same year, they might have to wait that one-week period unless they also qualify for having that wait period waived.
section_text:
A one week waiting period must be served when an initial benefit period is established for family caregiver benefits    . However, when the family caregiver benefits are shared between family members only one waiting period has to be served in relation to each care recipient and to each 52 week window. 
When these benefits are shared, the first eligible claimant making an initial claim for benefits is required to serve the waiting period. The waiting period may be deferred for the other family members sharing these benefits, provided that a waiting period has been served by one of the family members in relation to that care recipient and for the same 52 week window    .
 Where two eligible family members make a claim for family caregiver benefits at the same time, in relation to the same care recipient, the claimants will be required to choose which one will serve the waiting period.
It should be noted that, based on the wording of the legislation, the first claimant claiming family caregiver benefits must serve a one-week waiting period in its entirety, in order for the other family member(s) to have the waiting period deferred.
The current policy on waiving the waiting period continues to apply    . In situations where the waiting period was waived for the first person claiming family caregiver benefits, the second person establishing an initial benefit period for the same care recipient within the same window will be required to serve the waiting period. However, if the second claimant also meets the conditions to have the waiting period waived, this can be done.

simplified_text: When you're getting EI family caregiver benefits and you earn money, you have to tell them. They will reduce your benefits by 50 cents for every dollar you earn. This reduction can go up to 90% of the amount of money they used to figure out your EI benefits. If you earn more than that, they will take away the extra money you made from your benefits. You can find more details about this in Digest Chapter 1.9.8 or on the Government of Canada website.
section_text: Any earnings received while in receipt of EI family caregiver benefits must be declared and will be deducted from benefits at a rate of 50  cents of EI benefits for every dollar earned or received while on claim, up to a maximum of 90 percent of the weekly earnings used to establish their EI benefit rate. Any earnings above this threshold are deducted dollar for dollar from benefits  .\nDetailed information on the rules regarding the deduction of earnings while receiving benefits can be found in Digest Chapter 1.9.8 - Earnings while on claim and on the Government of Canada website   .

simplified_text: Family caregiver benefits, maternity benefits for pregnancy, parental benefits for caring for a new or adopted child, sickness benefits for illness or injury, and compassionate care benefits for looking after a family member with a serious medical condition are called special benefits. These benefits have certain rules for when they can be paid and a limit to how many weeks they can be paid for. The maximum number of weeks for special benefits is determined by the law, and this will be discussed in the next section.
section_title: Family caregiver benefits as part of special benefits
section_text: Family caregiver benefits, together with those benefits paid because of pregnancy (maternity benefits), to care for a new born or adopted child (parental benefits), because of illness, injury, or quarantine (sickness benefits), or to care for a family member with a serious medical condition (compassionate care benefits), are known collectively as special benefits and have specific requirements for payment, as well as limits to the number of weeks payable. \nThe maximum number of weeks for which special benefits may be paid has been set by legislation. These parameters are explained in the following section.

simplified_text:
Each type of special benefits under EI has a maximum number of weeks it can be paid during one benefit period. Here are the individual maximums: 15 weeks for maternity benefits, 35 weeks for standard parental benefits, or 61 weeks for extended parental benefits, 26 weeks for sickness benefits, 26 weeks for compassionate care benefits, 35 weeks for family caregiver benefits for children, and 15 weeks for family caregiver benefits for adults. You can receive special benefits for a total of 50 weeks during the initial benefit period, combining regular and special benefits.

However, it is possible to receive a maximum of 102 weeks of combined special benefits during the initial benefit period, with the period extended to a maximum of 104 weeks under specific conditions. These conditions include not receiving regular benefits, receiving more than one type of special benefits, and getting at least one of those special benefits for fewer weeks than the maximum allowed, with the total weeks exceeding 50. If a particular special benefit was not paid during the initial period, it cannot be paid during the extended period. The initial benefit period ends when either 50 weeks of special benefits have been paid or 51 weeks have passed since the start of the benefit period, plus any weeks from specific situations like being in jail, receiving severance pay, workers' compensation, or under provincial laws for specific safety reasons.

If you don't qualify for regular benefits but do for special benefits due to certain exceptions, you will only receive special benefits. The limit on the number of weeks of special benefits includes benefits from the Quebec Parental Insurance Plan. Each week of benefits from the Quebec plan is counted towards the maximum number of weeks you can receive EI maternity or parental benefits in one benefit period.
section_title: Limits to the number of weeks of special benefits payable
section_text:
Each type of EI special benefits has an individual maximum number of weeks that can be paid in one benefit period. The individual maximums are: 15 weeks for maternity benefits; 35 weeks for standard parental benefits or 61 weeks for extended parental benefits; 26 weeks for sickness benefits; 26 weeks for compassionate care benefits; 35 weeks for family caregiver benefits for children and 15 weeks for family caregiver benefits for adults. 
Special benefits may be paid in any combination during a benefit period, provided the claimant proves entitlement for each type of benefit.
A maximum of 50 weeks of benefits can be paid in the initial benefit period, when regular and special benefits are combined.
However, a maximum of 102 weeks  of combined special benefits may be payable and the initial benefit period  extended to a maximum of 104 weeks, if, during that initial benefit period:

No regular benefits were paid to the claimant; 
More than one type of special benefits was paid; and at least one of these  special benefits was paid for fewer than the applicable maximum number of weeks  payable for these special benefits, and
The maximum total number of weeks payable for the types of special benefits  requested is greater than 50.

If a specific type of special benefits was not paid during the initial benefit period, it cannot be paid during the extended benefit period.
The initial benefit period ends on the earlier of:

When 50 weeks of special benefits have been paid; or
Benefit period start date plus 51 weeks plus any weeks of extension due to work-sharing or for one of the following reasons
        
Confined in a jail, penitentiary or other similar institution and was not found guilty of the offence for which the claimant was being held or any other offence arising out of the same transaction;
In receipt of earnings paid because of the complete severance of their relationship with their former employer;
In receipt of workers' compensation payments for an illness or injury;

            or
In receipt of payments under a provincial law on the basis of having ceased to work because continuing to work would have resulted in danger to the claimant, her unborn child or a child whom she was breast-feeding.



A claimant who does not qualify for regular benefits under the EI Act , but qualifies for special benefits because of the regulatory exception, can only receive special benefits.
The limit to the number of weeks of special benefits payable also includes benefits paid under the Quebec Parental Insurance Plan. According to a specific regulatory provision, each week of Quebec Parental Insurance Plan benefits paid is considered as a week for which benefits are paid under the EI program, and is taken into consideration in calculating the overall maximum number of weeks of EI maternity or parental benefits to be paid per benefit period, and the maximum number of weeks of EI benefits to be paid regarding a birth or an adoption.

simplified_text: The rules that affect other parts of the Employment Insurance Act while receiving family caregiver benefits are explained in the upcoming sections.
section_title: Family caregiver benefits with respect to other provisions of the Employment Insurance Act
section_text: The impacts of other provisions of the Employment Insurance Act during the payment of family caregiver benefits are covered in the sections that follow.

simplified_text: Fishermen can qualify for family caregiver benefits if they have worked in fishing and earned at least $3,760 during a specific period. If a fisherman has a violation on record, they will need to have earned more than $3,760. Fishermen, like others applying for benefits, can receive these special benefits for up to 102 weeks.
section_text: Fishers can establish a claim for family caregiver benefits based on their insurable employment in fishing. They will be entitled to family caregiver benefits if they are major attached, meaning they have $3,760 or more, of insurable earnings as a fisher, in their qualifying period. However, if a fisher has accumulated a violation, more than $3,760 of insurable earnings will be required.\nLike other claimants, fishers are entitled to receive special benefits to a maximum of 102 weeks.

simplified_text: The law says that if someone is getting special benefits like family caregiver benefits, any disqualification from something will be put on hold. It also says that if someone is not allowed to get Employment Insurance benefits for reasons mentioned in sections 31 to 33 of the EI Act, this restriction will be put on hold so they can still get special benefits like family caregiver benefits.
section_text: The legislation provides that any disqualification will be deferred or suspended during the period that a claimant is in receipt of special benefits, including family caregiver benefits. There is also a provision stating that any disentitlement under sections 31 to 33 of the EI Act will be suspended to allow the claimant to receive any special benefits, including family caregiver benefits.

simplified_text:
If you can't work because of a strike at your job, you may be able to still get family caregiver benefits. To do this, you must prove that you were already approved for time off to take care of a sick family member before the strike started. 
If you are already getting family caregiver benefits when a strike happens, you can keep getting them during the strike. But if you can't go back to work once the benefits end because of the strike, you may lose those benefits.
section_text: A claimant who is subject to a disentitlement because of a labour dispute at his or her place of employment, may have that disentitlement suspended, in order to receive family caregiver benefits, subject to proving entitlement to those benefits.\nBefore the disentitlement can be suspended, the claimant must prove that a leave of absence to provide care or support to a critically ill care recipient was approved, or arrangements to be absent from work for this purpose, had begun with the employer, before the start of the work stoppage.\nA claimant who is in receipt of family caregiver benefits when a stoppage of work occurs will not be affected by the provisions of the Act relating to labour disputes during the period that claimant is in receipt of those benefits. However, a disentitlement may be imposed when the family caregiver benefits end, if the claimant is unable to resume his or her previous employment, because of a stoppage of work attributable to a labour dispute .

simplified_text: A teacher can get family caregiver benefits even during school breaks, if they meet all the requirements for receiving these benefits.
section_text: A claimant employed in teaching may receive family caregiver benefits during both the teaching and non-teaching periods , provided all other entitlement criteria for the payment of these benefits, are met.

simplified_text: If someone is not in Canada but is taking care of a seriously ill family member, they can get family caregiver benefits as long as their Social Insurance Number is still valid. They do not need to show that they are available to work to receive these benefits, and they won't lose the benefits just because they are outside of Canada.
section_text: A claimant who is outside Canada temporarily or permanently, is entitled to family caregiver benefits, for the purpose of providing care or support to a critically ill care recipient, unless their Social Insurance Number has expired. A claimant in receipt of these benefits is not required to prove availability for work, and will not be disentitled for the sole reason of being out of the country.

simplified_text: If you have a family member who is critically ill and lives outside of Canada, you may need to go to their country to take care of them. In this case, you will need to provide a medical certificate from a doctor or nurse practitioner with the same information as if the ill family member was living in Canada.
section_title: Critically ill family member resides outside Canada
section_text: A critically care recipient may not always reside in Canada.  A claimant may be required to leave Canada to provide care or support to this care recipient . It will be necessary for the claimant to submit a medical certificate from a medical doctor or nurse practitioner, providing the same information that is required when the critically ill care recipient resides in Canada.

simplified_text:
In some cases, people can receive regular employment insurance benefits even if they are outside of Canada. If someone is getting family caregiver benefits while they are outside Canada, the rules for those benefits are different from the rules for regular benefits. 

For family caregivers, their benefits normally stop when the critically ill person they are caring for passes away. But if they need time off to attend the funeral, they might still be able to get regular benefits depending on certain rules.
section_title: Other out of Canada situations and family caregiver benefits
section_text: There are other reasons set out in Regulation 55(1) which allow payment of regular EI benefits while outside Canada   . When a claimant is in receipt of family caregiver benefits while outside of Canada, entitlement to those benefits is adjudicated independently from the reasons set out in Regulation 55(1).\nFor the purposes of parents of family caregiver benefits, while entitlement to these benefits would cease at the end of the week in which the critically ill care recipient dies, claimants may require additional time off to attend the funeral. The existing adjudication principles should be applied in these situations to determine if the claimant could be entitled to regular benefits if the funeral is outside Canada.

simplified_text: Family caregiver benefits are given to people who take care of a family member who is very sick. Claiming these benefits doesn't mean you can't do anything else. You can still attend a class if you also take care of the sick family member. You don't have to look for other work to get these benefits.\nWhen you're not busy with something else, you're still considered to be taking care of the sick family member. Even if you can't give care during a class, you can still get the benefits. But if you stop taking care of the sick family member for another reason, you might not qualify for the benefits anymore. Each situation is looked at separately.\nSometimes, it might be decided that you're not really taking care of the sick family member. For example, if you leave the sick family member with someone else and move far away to go to school, you might not qualify for the benefits because you're not providing care anymore. Each case is considered on its own facts.
section_text:
Family caregiver benefits are payable to eligible claimants who are providing care or support to a critically ill care recipient.
However, an individual claiming these benefits is not expected to cease all other activity. As long as the eligible claimant is providing the necessary care or support for the critically ill care recipient, and depending on the number of hours devoted to the course of instruction, it is acceptable to attend a course of instruction on the claimant's own initiative, while in receipt of family caregiver benefits, as availability for work is not a factor in determining entitlement to receive these benefits.
The individual can still be considered to be providing care or support to the critically ill care recipient, when doing so outside the hours of another activity. The fact that a claimant may not provide direct care while devoting time to the course of instruction, does not mean that the claimant will automatically be denied benefits. However, when the claimant's reason for not working is not, or ceases to be, to care for the critically ill care recipient, entitlement to family caregiver benefits is not proven, and the claimant may be subject to a disentitlement. The circumstances of each case must be considered individually.
There may be situations where it may be determined that a claimant is not meeting the condition of providing care or support to the critically ill care recipient. An example of this would be where the claimant, who is receiving these benefits, leaves the critically ill care recipient withanother family member in Ottawa and moves to Vancouver to attend a course, thereby not providing care or support to the critically ill care recipient, for an extended period of time. The claimant in that case would have a difficult time proving he was providing care or support to the critically ill care recipient, within the meaning of the Act. Again, each case must be determined on its own merits.

simplified_text: To sign up for a training program or job opportunity through Section 25 of the EI Act, you need to be someone who doesn't have a job. Usually, if you're getting family caregiver benefits, it means you're taking time off work to care for a family member, so you're not considered someone without a job. Because of this, people who are on family caregiver leave don't normally get offered these training programs or job opportunities. You can find more details about getting family caregiver benefits while taking part in an approved program or job activity referred to by a certain authority in Chapter 19.2.6 of the Digest. Also, in Chapter 19.2.7, you can learn about what happens if you stop a program or job you were referred to under Section 25 of the EI Act to take care of a seriously ill family member.
section_title: Approved course or other employment activity under Section 25 of the EI Act
section_text:
In order to be referred to a course of instruction or employment activity under  Section 25 of the EI Act, the claimant must be an unemployed worker.  Generally it is assumed that claimants who are collecting family caregiver benefits are on a leave of absence from their employment, and would not be unemployed workers as they have a job to return to. Generally, referrals to an approved course or employment activity under Section 25 of the EI Act would not be made for these claimants.
See Chapter 19.2.6 of the Digest for more information on entitlement to family caregiver benefits while attending an approved course or other employment activities, to which a claimant was referred by a designated authority, under Section 25 of the EI Act.
See Chapter 19.2.7 of the Digest for more information on disqualification from benefits, where a claimant withdraws from a course or employment activity to which they were referred under Section 25 of the EI Act, to provide care and support to a critically ill care recipient.


Report navigation


 Previous part of report

simplified_text:
In January 2004, a new law called Employment Insurance (EI) introduced benefits for compassionate care. These benefits help people who need to take time off work to care for a family member who is very sick and might pass away within 26 weeks. To get this support, you don't have to be available for work. The law was updated in January 2016 to increase the maximum number of weeks you can get these benefits and how long you can get them for. 

Now, you can receive up to 26 weeks of compassionate care benefits within a 52-week period. This support can be given to one family member or shared among family members. You can only get a maximum of 26 weeks per time you apply for benefits.

The law also gives guidelines about what qualifies as care or support, who can give the needed paperwork, when a shorter time period might apply, when you can delay the waiting period, and what to do if family members can't agree on how to split up the benefits.

In this law, a seriously ill family member is referred to as someone with a medical condition where death could happen within 26 weeks.
section_text:
In January 2004, the Employment Insurance (EI) legislation introduced compassionate care benefits. These benefits allow an eligible claimant to receive income support while absent from work to provide care or support for a family member with a serious medical condition and a significant risk of death within 26 weeks. Individuals are not required to be available for work to receive this type of benefits. The EI legislation has been updated effective January 3, 2016, to increase the maximum number of weeks of compassionate care benefits that may be paid, and the length of the window during which these benefits may be payable.
The legislation provides for the payment of a maximum of 26 weeks of compassionate care benefits within a 52 week window, whether they are paid to one family member, or shared between family members. A claimant can only receive a maximum of 26 weeks of compassionate care benefits per benefit period.
The Act provides for the making of regulations to further define and determine what is care or support; who can issue a medical certificate; in which situations a shorter period than 52 weeks applies; when a waiting period can be deferred; and prescribing rules when family members do not agree on the division of weeks of benefits.
Throughout this chapter, for ease of reference, the expression gravely ill family member, or patient, is used to describe a family member who has a serious medical condition with a significant risk of death within 26 weeks.

simplified_text: The law states that compassionate care benefits can be paid to someone who is the main caregiver for a seriously ill family member. The family member must have a medical condition with a high risk of death within 26 weeks. The benefits start either from the day the medical certificate is issued, or earlier if the claim was made before the certificate was issued. The family member must need care or support from other family members.
section_text:
The legislative authority to pay compassionate care benefits reads as follows: 
Notwithstanding Section 18, but subject to this section, benefits are payable to a major attachment claimant if a medical doctor has issued a certificate stating that

a family member of the claimant has a serious medical condition with a significant risk of death within 26 weeks       
from the day the certificate is issued,
in the case of a claim that is made before the day the certificate is issued, from the day from which the medical doctor certifies the family member's medical condition, or
in the case of a claim that is regarded to have been made on an earlier day under subsection 10(4) or (5), from that earlier day; and


the family member requires the care or support of one or more other family members.

simplified_text: Compassionate care benefits are there to help people take care of a family member who is very sick and might pass away within six months.
section_text: Compassionate care benefits are available to an eligible claimant for the purpose of providing care or support to a seriously ill family member with a significant risk of death within 26 weeks  .

simplified_text: To qualify for compassionate care benefits, you must be taking care of a family member who is seriously ill. A family member, in this case, includes: your spouse or common-law partner, your child and their spouse or partner, your parent and their spouse or partner, your siblings and their spouses or partners, your grandparents and their partners, your grandchildren and their partners, your uncles, aunts, nieces, nephews and their partners, current or former foster family members, current or former wards, current or former guardians, and anyone who is like a close relative to you, even if not related by blood, adoption, marriage, or common-law partnership.
section_title: Family members who can receive compassionate care benefits
section_text:
For the purpose of entitlement to compassionate care benefits, the term family member in relation to the individual who is seriously ill, applies to the following individuals:   

spouse or common-law partner 
child, their spouse or common-law partner
child of spouse or common-law partner, their       spouse or common-law partner
parent, their spouse or common-law partner
parent of spouse or common-law partner, their       spouse or common-law partner
sibling, step-sibling, their spouse or       common-law partner
sibling, step-sibling of spouse or common-law       partner
grandparent, their spouse or common-law       partner
grandparent of spouse or common-law partner
grandchild, their spouse or common-law partner
grandchild of spouse or common-law partner
uncle, aunt, their spouse or common-law       partner
uncle, aunt of spouse or common-law partner
nephew, niece, their spouse or common-law       partner
nephew, niece of spouse or common-law partner
current or former foster parent
current or former foster parent of spouse or common-law       partner
current or former foster child, their spouse       or common-law partner
current or former ward
current or former ward of spouse or common-law       partner
current or former guardian, their spouse or       common-law partner or
a person who is considered to be like a close       relative, whether or not related by blood, adoption, marriage or       common-law partnership

simplified_text: To get compassionate care benefits, you need to have temporarily stopped working and have worked at least 600 hours in your job within a specific time frame. If you've had issues before with your employment insurance, you might need more than 600 hours of work to qualify for these benefits. Even if you're currently getting EI benefits because you're jobless, you can still apply for compassionate care benefits. You must provide a medical document showing that your family member is seriously ill to be eligible for these benefits. If you're self-employed and opted into the EI program, you can also access compassionate care benefits.
section_text:
The individual claiming compassionate care benefits must have experienced an interruption of earnings from employment, and be major attached, that is, have 600 hours of insurable employment in their qualifying period.
In situations where a claimant has accumulated a violation, the claimant will require more than 600 hours of insurable employment during the qualifying periodto be entitled to compassionate care benefits.
Individuals who are unemployed and already receiving EI benefits can also apply for and be entitled to compassionate care benefits.
The individual claiming compassionate care benefits must submit a medical certificate with regard to the seriously ill family member.
Compassionate care benefits are accessible to self-employed persons who have voluntarily registered into the EI program.

simplified_text:
An eligible person who wants to apply for compassionate benefits must provide a signed medical document from a doctor or nurse who is treating their seriously ill family member. The doctor or nurse will confirm that the family member meets two conditions: they have a severe medical condition that could lead to death within 26 weeks and they need care from a family member.

If the ill family member lives outside of Canada, a medical document from a doctor or nurse with similar qualifications to those in Canada will be accepted. The document should include the family member's full name, address, and date of birth. If multiple family members are applying for benefits, only one medical document is needed.

Medical professionals cannot share a patient's medical information without their permission or unless required by law. The patient must sign a form allowing the doctor to share their medical information with the Commission. If the patient is unable to consent due to age or health reasons, their legal representative can sign the form. Failure to include this authorization with the medical document will result in benefits being denied.
section_title: Proof of seriously ill family member
section_text:
An eligible claimant must submit a medical certificate signed by a medical doctor or nurse practitioner treating the seriously ill family member. The medical doctor or nurse practitioner will attest to the fact that his or her patient, the seriously ill family member, meets the following 2 conditions. The patient:

has a serious medical condition with a significant risk of death within 26 weeks, and
requires the care or support of one or more family members

Where the seriously ill family member resides outside of Canada, a medical certificate issued by a medical doctor or nurse practitioner recognized by the appropriate government authority with similar qualifications to a medical doctor or nurse practitioner in Canada is acceptable.
The certificate will identify the seriously ill family member - the doctor or nurse practitioner's patient - by providing the complete name, address and date of birth of the patient. When more than one claimant will share the compassionate benefits, only one certificate is required.
Medical professionals are not authorized to release medical information without the patient's consent, or unless required by law. A separate form must be signed by the patient, to authorize the medical doctor or nurse practitioner to release medical information on the patient, to the Commission. If the patient is incapable of consenting to the release of medical information for reasons of his/her age or a physical or mental condition, the authorization form must be completed by the patient's legally authorized or appointed representative. If a medical certificate is not accompanied by the authorization to release medical information for the patient, the claimant will be disentitled from benefits.

simplified_text:
Taking care of a very sick family member involves directly taking care of them, providing emotional support, or arranging for someone else to take care of them. This care can be given in person at home, a hospice, or a medical facility. 

If someone is receiving benefits for this kind of care, and they need a short break due to the stress it causes, they won't automatically lose their benefits. Each case will be considered individually. 

Sometimes, the person providing care might not live in the same area as the sick family member but can still arrange for care or give emotional support from a distance. 

However, if it seems like the person getting benefits isn't actually providing care or support, they will stop receiving those benefits, regardless of their location.
section_title: Care or support of seriously ill family member
section_text:
Care or support of a seriously ill family member includes;

directly providing or participating in the care of the family member, or
providing psychological and emotional support to the family member, or
arranging for care of the family member by a third party care provider.

The definition of care or support includes direct as well as indirect care and support. It also includes situations where the claimant simply spends time each day with the seriously ill family member in the home, a hospice or a medical facility.
Any period during which an individual is claiming this type of benefit is a time of great personal stress and the claimant may require a short break from providing care or support for the seriously ill family member in order to deal with this stress. Therefore benefits would not be automatically denied when the claimant does not actually provide care for only a few days. The determination of whether the claimant continues to prove entitlement to these benefits will be based on the merits of each individual case.
There will be situations where the claimant resides in a different geographical area than the seriously ill family member and may arrange for the delivery of care or may provide psychological and emotional support from wherever he or she resides. The legislation provides the opportunity to respond to these situations.
In any situation, if it becomes apparent that the claimant is not providing care or support, based on the definition above, the claimant will be disentitled from benefits. This would apply whether the claimant is in the same geographical area as the seriously ill family member or not.

simplified_text: The law says you can get a maximum of 26 weeks of compassionate care benefits in one period of time for a seriously ill family member. You can use those 26 weeks in a 52-week period. These rules apply whether you're the only one getting the benefits or if you're sharing them with another family member.
section_title: The number of weeks for which compassionate care benefits may be paid
section_text:
The legislation provides two limits to the maximum number of weeks of compassionate care benefits payable.

The first is a maximum of 26 weeks of compassionate care benefits payable within a benefit period
The second is a maximum of 26 weeks in a 52 week window in relation to the seriously ill family member.

These limitations apply whether the benefits are claimed by one individual or shared with another family member.

simplified_text: Compassionate care benefits are there for people who qualify, and they can be received for up to 52 weeks. These benefits are for someone who needs to look after a family member who is very sick and might pass away within 26 weeks. You can get the benefits for up to 26 weeks during this 52 week period. To get these benefits, you need to have a medical certificate and ask for the benefits for the first time as a family member.
section_text: Compassionate care benefits are available to eligible claimants within a 52 week window, to provide care or support to a family member who is seriously ill with a significant risk of death within 26 weeks. This 52 week window during which 26 weeks of compassionate care benefits may be payable, is determined by both the issuance of a medical certificate and a first request for these benefits by a family member.

simplified_text:
This section of the Employment Insurance Act talks about compassionate care benefits. It explains when these benefits can start being paid. 

- The benefits can start from the week when the first valid medical certificate is given to the authorities.
- If the claim was made before the certificate was issued, benefits can start from when the doctor confirms the family member's medical condition.
- If there's a request to backdate the claim, benefits can begin from the requested earlier date.

Once the 52-week period starts, it cannot be changed. If a new certificate says the family member was ill before, benefits won't change if:
- All entitled benefits have already been paid.
- The 52-week period has been set, and the certificate tries to move it back.
- Any other circumstances listed in the Regulations exist.

Right now, there are no Regulations defining these other circumstances. This rule makes sure that later certificates won't affect benefits paid to another person for the same sick family member.

Sometimes, a new certificate changes details from an old one. In this case, the claim can be reconsidered while following the compassionate care law.
section_title: Start of the compassionate care window
section_text:
Subsection 23.1 (4) of the EI Act states that compassionate care benefits can be paid in the period that begins in the week in which the following falls:

the day of issuance of the first valid medical certificate that is submitted to the Commission,
in the case of a claim that is made before the day the medical certificate is issued, the day from which the medical doctor certifies the family member's medical condition, or
in the case of a request to consider that the claim is made at an earlier date, at that earlier day.

The first medical certificate submitted that meets the requirements of the legislation will determine the start of the 52 week window. Once the start week of the window has been established, it cannot be changed. The legislation provides that a subsequent certificate which indicates that the conditions of entitlement applied to the seriously ill family member on an earlier date will not be accepted to change the start of the window when:

all benefits that may otherwise have been payable in relation to that claim have already been paid at the time the certificate is filed with the Commission, or
the start of the 52 week window has already been determined regarding the seriously ill family member, and the certificate would have the effect of moving the beginning of that period to an earlier date; or
the claim is made in any other circumstances set out in the Regulations.

N.B. At present there are no Regulations defining any other circumstances.
This provision will ensure that a subsequent certificate submitted will not impact any compassionate care benefits already paid to another claimant, for the same seriously ill family member.
There may be rare cases where a medical certificate is received with an amendment to the information provided on a previous medical certificate. As in any other situation where amended information is received, the claim may be reconsidered, keeping in mind the provisions of the compassionate care legislation.

simplified_text: If you get a medical certificate before you apply for compassionate leave, a 52-week period begins. This period starts from either the day the doctor examines the seriously ill family member and confirms two things: the patient has a severe medical condition with a high risk of dying within the next 26 weeks, and they need the care of one or more family members, or the day the doctor states that these two conditions were met earlier.
section_title: Medical certificate  issued before compassionate care claimed
section_text:
Where the medical certificate is issued before the compassionate claim is made, the 52 week window starts with the earlier of:

the date of examination of the seriously ill family member where the doctor certifies that the two conditions exist: the patient has a serious medical condition and a significant risk of death within the next 26 weeks and the patient requires the care of support of one or more family members, or
the date which the medical doctor or practitioner attests that the two conditions applied at an earlier period of time.

simplified_text:
The 52-week period for compassionate care benefits begins with the date that the medical certificate is signed by a doctor, the date of the examination of the seriously ill family member (where the doctor confirms the patient's serious condition and risk of death within 26 weeks, requiring care from family), or the date the doctor verifies that the conditions were met at an earlier time.

If you are seeking benefits for weeks before the certificate was signed, the date can be the last medical exam date or a time when the conditions were met, as stated in the medical records. The start date for the 52-week period should be chosen to cover the weeks you are claiming.

If the medical certificate is signed before the start of the compassionate care weeks being claimed, that signature date can also be used as the beginning of the 52-week window.
section_title: Medical certificate issued after compassionate care claimed
section_text:
Where the medical certificate is issued after compassionate care benefits are claimed, the 52 week window starts with the earlier of:

the date the certificate is signed by the medical doctor or practitioner, or
the date of examination of the seriously ill family member where the doctor certifies that the two conditions exist: the patient has a serious medical condition and a significant risk of death within the next 26 weeks and the patient requires the care or support of one or more family members, or
the date which the medical doctor or practitioner attests that the two conditions applied at an earlier period of time.

Where benefits are requested for weeks prior to the week of signature of the medical certificate, information that the conditions for compassionate care benefits applied to an earlier date may be present. This can be the date of the last medical examination or an earlier date on which the conditions applied, as indicated in the medical, rather than the date of signature. The date which will be used to start the 52 week window should be the one which will accommodate the weeks the claimant is requesting.
The week the medical doctor or practitioner signed the certificate can also be used as the start week of the window, when the date of signature is prior to the compassionate care weeks being claimed.

simplified_text:
The compassionate care window lasts for 52 weeks. During this time, a person can receive up to 26 weeks of benefits for taking care of a seriously ill family member. These 26 weeks don't have to be taken all at once and can be spread out over the 52-week period. The benefits stop once one of the following happens: the 52-week window ends, all 26 weeks of benefits have been used, or the ill family member passes away.

If the ill family member recovers or the illness improves, the benefits stop when the caregiver is no longer needed. In cases where the illness comes back or remains the same after the initial 52 weeks, a new period of benefits can be applied for with proper medical documentation.

For example, if John takes care of his sick mom from August to December 2016, and his sister Tammie takes over from January to June 2017, Tammie can receive additional benefits if their mom's condition worsens again.
section_text:
